natural problem: Add 313.9 to 12.6. Express the result as a decimal.
natural solution: We have \[ \begin{array}{@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & \\ & 3 & 1 & 3. & 9 \\ + & & 1 & 2. & 6 \\ \cline{1-5} & 3 & 2 & 6. & 5 \\ \end{array} \]Since $9+6=15$ in the right-most column is greater than 9, we record the 5 and "carry" the 10 to the next column as a 1 (shown over the second 3 in the addend 313.9).

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 313.9"
and h1 : "y = 12.6"
shows  "x + y = 326.5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add 313.9 to 12.6. Express the result as a decimal. The final Answer is 326.5
 ### Proof
 We have \[ \begin{array}{@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & & 1 & \\ & 3 & 1 & 3. & 9 \\ + & & 1 & 2. & 6 \\ \cline{1-5} & 3 & 2 & 6. & 5 \\ \end{array} \]Since $9+6=15$ in the right-most column is greater than 9, we record the 5 and "carry" the 10 to the next column as a 1 (shown over the second 3 in the addend 313.9).
 The answer is $\boxed{326.5}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 313.9"
and h1 : "y = 12.6"
shows  "x + y = 326.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Add 313.9 and 12.6. The final answer is 326.5.
